persona.name: Carlos Rivera

occupation.title: Unemployed (seeking work / informal day laborer on occasion)
occupation.description: Currently unemployed in formal terms. Historically has worked intermittently in informal and manual jobs: day laborer on construction sites, helper for a local carpenter, occasional vendor at a mercado, and short-term gigs moving appliances. Responsibilities when employed included heavy lifting, basic masonry tasks, mixing cement, loading/unloading trucks, helping with simple installations, and doing repair work around neighbors' houses for small cash payments. He is used to unpredictable schedules, cash-in-hand payment, and bargaining for higher pay for hard tasks. He can operate basic hand and power tools, understands construction site safety informally, and has basic knowledge of materials and local supply stores. Major difficulty: irregular income, limited access to formal job channels and references, lack of recent formal credentials. Skills and practical knowledge exist but are undervalued in the formal job market. He actively looks for day labor through his neighborhood union of trabajadores or via acquaintances in construction but struggles to secure steady full-time employment.

persona.education: High school diploma (completed secondary education at a public preparatoria). Took some evening vocational classes in basic welding and electrical repair but did not finish the certificate program.
long_term_goals: Provide a stable home and good education for his children so they don’t have to struggle the way he did.
Find steady formal employment or a stable microbusiness that can lift the family out of precarious monthly budgets.
Save enough to buy or at least make a down payment on a small apartment rather than renting a cramped place.
Learn a trade properly (plumbing or electrical) and obtain formal certification to earn higher, more reliable wages.
Be a present, emotionally available father who teaches his children useful skills and cultural pride.
Repair and improve the family home so his children have a safer, healthier environment to grow up in.
Reconnect with an extended family member he has grown distant from and rebuild a support network.
Be able to take his family on a modest vacation outside the city once every few years.
Teach his children to read well and help them with basic numeracy so school is easier for them.
Leave a legacy of hard work and integrity so his children feel secure and proud of their roots.
persona.style: Direct, colloquial Mexico City Spanish with a working-class Ciudad de México accent. Uses local idioms ("órale", "ya vuiste", "ándale") and often mixes in brief English words when referring to electronics or appliances. Speaks quickly when excited, slows down and becomes reflective when discussing family or problems. Mannerisms: rubs the back of his neck when embarrassed, taps surfaces rhythmically when thinking, smiles broadly and shows teeth when trying to charm or diffuse uncomfortable moments. Communication tends to be pragmatic and concrete — he prefers giving and hearing actionable advice. In social situations he is warm and joking with neighbors but guarded about finances and personal failures. Typically dresses for practicality: worn jeans, inexpensive shirts, a lightweight work jacket, sturdy sneakers or work boots. At home he loosens his posture, speaks softly to his children and wife, and uses a lot of diminutives when talking to the kids ("mi chiquito", "mi manita"). He prefers face-to-face conversations for important matters, dislikes long bureaucratic phone calls, and often uses WhatsApp voice messages to communicate quickly with relatives.

traits: Practical — focuses on immediate, solvable problems and treats abstract speculation with suspicion.
Resilient — has bounced back from short-term crises several times and keeps trying.
Protective — prioritizes the safety and emotional comfort of his wife and children.
Short-tempered under stress — can raise his voice when frustrated but rarely resorts to aggression.
Good-humored — uses jokes and self-deprecation to ease tension and bond socially.
Skeptical of institutions — mistrustful of banks, authorities, and unfamiliar NGOs.
Loyal — once he commits to people (family, long-term friends, co-workers) he tends to stay true.
Resourceful — improvises repairs, repurposes materials, and finds alternative ways to meet needs.
Emotionally available in family contexts — will cry quietly at milestones and shows pride openly.
Avoidant about personal failures — tends not to speak fully about debts or serious health fears.
Caring — small acts of care (making soup, warming a blanket, waking early for chores) are frequent.
Modestly ambitious — desires improvement but worries about tradeoffs and risks of overextending.

big_five.openness: Low-Medium. Practical curiosity about skills and tools but little appetite for abstract art or avant-garde ideas.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium. Dependable in daily family responsibilities and work routines when employed, but organization around paperwork, finances, and long-term planning is inconsistent.
big_five.extraversion: Medium. Social and friendly in his neighborhood and with co-workers, but selectively reserved with strangers and officials.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Cooperative, helpful, and empathetic, especially within his circle; dislikes conflict but will stand up for family.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-High. Worries about money and children's future; sometimes experiences sleepless nights and anxiety, especially when bills pile up.

interests: Watching football (soccer) — follows Club América and local neighborhood teams; watches matches with neighborhood friends.
Simple home-cooked meals — likes to cook caldos and slow-simmered stews when time allows.
Fixing things — enjoys troubleshooting broken appliances, furniture, and plumbing with improvised solutions.
Neighborhood social life — participates in colonia events, small festivals, and street soccer games.
Listening to regional Mexican music (ranchera, banda) and some modern Latin pop on the radio.
Watching family-friendly shows and comedies in the evening; nostalgic about 1990s Mexican TV.
Keeping up with kids — enjoys kids' cartoons, songs, and playing simple games with them.
Handicrafts — respects carpentry and metalwork, admires local artisans and street vendors.
Smartphone content — spends time on WhatsApp groups, short Facebook videos, and practical how-to clips on YouTube.
Spending time outdoors in small doses — visits a nearby park with the kids on weekends.
Bargaining at markets — likes negotiating prices and finding good deals.
Barbecue — likes weekends grilling small cuts of meat for family visitors.
Following neighborhood gossip — keeps up with who moved in/out and local job opportunities.
Watching construction techniques — enjoys observing how new buildings go up and imagining improvements to his home.
Collecting small tools and spare parts — values utility over aesthetics.
Celebrating family traditions — enjoys birthday parties, baptisms, and small anniversaries.
Listening to elder relatives tell stories — values oral family history and anecdotes.
Learning small new skills through free community classes when available.
Visiting the mercado on Saturdays — likes the bustling atmosphere and fresh produce.
Using radio to hear local news and traffic updates.
likes: Child-friendly spaces and playgrounds where his kids can run safely.
Cheap, filling street food: tortas, tlacoyos, tacos de guisado.
Stores with friendly owners who give small credit or accept delayed payment.
Tools that are rugged and simple to repair, not highly technical gadgets.
Neighbors who watch over each other's children.
Public festivals and free community events that entertain the family.
When a small repair holds up for months after his work — feeling pride in usefulness.
Listening to his mother-in-law's cooking advice.
Coffee in the morning strong and sweet, sometimes with a splash of evaporated milk.
A quiet nap after a long day of moving materials or doing odd jobs.
Using receipts and small notebooks to track daily cash flows when he remembers.
When employers show respect and pay on time.
A reliable second-hand pickup truck or cargo bike for moving small loads.
Finding bargains at tianguis (street markets) for kids' clothing.
When the children sleep through the night — his nights are noticeably better.
When an acquaintance refers him to a job — trust and social capital mean a lot.
Listening to simple, direct advice from older male friends who have similar backgrounds.
Having a weekend where bills are manageable and there's some extra for a treat.
Watching the kids learn something new and being able to teach them themselves.
Receiving a nod of recognition from a contractor who knows his work.
dislikes: Long, opaque bureaucratic processes and government forms.
Being dismissed or disrespected because of his education level or informal work.
High, unpredictable medical bills for himself or his children.
Any employer who delays wages or pays less than agreed.
Expensive, fragile gadgets that require store repairs.
Crowded clinics where waiting is long and service is curt.
Neighborhood petty theft and the fear of someone breaking into the house.
Talking about deep personal financial failures; he prefers to keep these private.
Authorities who ask for bribes or are openly corrupt.
Schools that are under-resourced and push kids through without attention.
Being offered training that costs money up front with uncertain returns.
Bank fees and minimum balance requirements that eat into small savings.
When his suggestions for fixing something are ignored by paid professionals.
Judgmental people who equate education level with moral worth.
Companies that advertise false promises (fake job offers).
The smell of damp mold in housing — fears health impacts on his children.
Long-distance commuting for low pay — energy and time lost are not worth it.
People who overpromise and underdeliver on helping his family.
Being patronized in front of his children.
Having to miss a child's event because of work.
consumption_habits: Buys fresh produce weekly at the local mercado, preferring to negotiate for better prices late in the morning.
Spends on children's needs first (diapers, school supplies) and delays personal purchases.
Occasional purchases at informal credit shops (commonly called 'abonos') when short on cash.
Prefers second-hand tools and clothing when quality is acceptable.
Uses prepaid mobile plans, topping up according to urgent needs.
Avoids formal loans unless absolutely necessary; when forced, uses micro-lenders known locally.
Eats most meals at home but allows for one or two cheap street-food treats on weekends.
Saves small cash amounts in a home envelope system and in informal rotating savings groups when he can.
media_and_tech: WhatsApp is his main communication and coordination tool with family and job contacts.
Listens to local radio in transit and while doing chores.
Uses YouTube for practical how-to videos rather than entertainment only.
Has a budget Android smartphone with limited storage; clears apps monthly to keep it usable.
Rarely uses email; prefers messaging or direct phone calls for anything urgent.
Watches football highlights and local matches streamed on low-data settings.

beliefs: Family obligations come before personal ambition — family must be protected even if personal dreams pause.
Hard physical work is honorable and builds character.
Formal education is valuable but often inaccessible; skills learned on the job are equally important.
Government programs can help but bureaucracies are often slow and confusing.
Neighbors and local relationships are a primary safety net in times of need.
Children should be taught respect for elders and the importance of schooling.
Debt is dangerous but sometimes unavoidable to get through emergency months.
One should pay back favors and maintain reciprocal relationships — loyalty matters.
Employers should pay on time and treat day laborers with dignity.
Having tools and basic skills increases independence and reduces long-term costs.
Religion and cultural rituals provide comfort and a sense of continuity (attends occasional mass and celebrations).
Authorities are to be approached cautiously; some are helpful, others exploit vulnerability.
Local small businesses are the backbone of the community; supporting them keeps the neighborhood alive.
Schools should teach both academic and practical life skills.
Education in trades is a reliable route out of precarity.
Health is important but preventive care is often neglected due to cost and time.
Children's laughter and small milestones are the true measure of success.
Pride in manual skill is respectable — knowing how to fix things is a point of identity.
Being known by the market vendor's name is a sign of social integration and trust.
Work that pays in cash is useful for immediate cash flow even if benefits are lacking.
Borrowing from a trusted friend is preferable to predatory lenders.
The older generation's advice, even if imperfect, contains practical wisdom.
A little fun now (a small family treat) is important for morale when times are tough.
Solidarity among neighbors should be mutual; if you help today, you can expect help tomorrow.
Kids learn more by watching parents than by listening to lectures.
Managing small savings consistently builds a safety cushion over time.
Being too proud to ask for help can make problems worse; asking discreetly is smart.
Good employers exist but are rare; networking and reputation matter more than CVs for many jobs.
Children who see their parents read and learn are more likely to value school.
Plastic money and credit cards seem risky; cash is simpler even if less secure.
Participation in local committees (comités de vecinos) can improve the neighborhood.
If you can fix something yourself, you avoid needless expenses and build confidence.
Mental health struggles are real but often invisible — men are expected to endure, which is unfair.
The state should provide more tangible support for childcare and early education.
A small emergency fund covering a month's expenses can prevent many crises.
People who gloat about success make him wary; humility and sharing are more admirable.
skills: Basic masonry: mixing cement, laying small walls, patching floors and steps.
Carpentry basics: measuring, sawing, sanding, common joinery, making simple shelves and kid furniture.
Hand and power tools: competent with drills, circular saws, hammers, wrenches, and basic welding equipment (self-taught).
Plumbing troubleshooting: unclogging drains, replacing washers, fixing minor leaks; knows when to call a specialist.
Electrical basics: changing outlets, replacing switches, installing simple light fixtures — knows when circuits are unsafe.
Appliance moving and installation: safe lifting techniques and securing items for transport.
Bargaining and negotiation skills in markets and with small employers.
Childcare: diapering, feeding, bathing, calming techniques, basic early childhood play and routines.
Cooking family meals on a tight budget with basic nutrition awareness.
Vehicle maintenance: changing oil, replacing brake pads, patching inner tubes on bikes; keeps a simple toolkit for emergencies.
Basic smartphone literacy: using WhatsApp, YouTube tutorials, map apps, and mobile banking top-ups.
Conflict resolution at a neighborhood level — mediator in small disputes about noise or shared courtyards.
Organizing small, ad-hoc teams of day laborers for moving or construction tasks.
Time management for daily tasks when juggling multiple odd jobs.
Adapting instructions quickly — learns by watching others and trying in small increments.

general: Habitually checks WhatsApp at dawn and again in the evening for gig opportunities and family coordination.
Often accepts small jobs from neighbors for repair work in exchange for partial payment or food.
Keeps receipts and small notes in a worn wallet envelope for weekly budgeting but doesn't always reconcile totals.
Smokes occasionally — mostly in social situations or when stressed, and tries to hide it from the children.
Shows physical affection openly with family: hugs, forehead kisses, and play wrestling with the kids.
Avoids showing extreme worry in front of children; presents a calm, positive front even when worried.
Pragmatically improvises solutions with duct tape, rope, and reclaimed wood.
Prefers face-to-face bargains; will follow up with a short voice message to confirm details.
Receives neighborhood gossip politely and sometimes contributes updates about jobs.
Gets visibly anxious when a bill collector calls or when rent is due.
Celebrates small victories loudly (a paid week of work, a repaired pipe) and shares with friends.
Keeps a small, trusted circle for loans and favors rather than large community chains.
Regularly attends a weekly informal meeting of local workers where jobs are discussed.

morning: Wakes between 5:30–6:30 AM on days when a potential day job is expected; otherwise around 7:00 AM.
Makes strong coffee, wakes children, helps with quick breakfasts (eggs, tortillas, beans), and dresses the younger child.
Checks WhatsApp groups and calls local contacts about day labor opportunities.
If hired for a job, he loads tools into a small cab or borrows a neighbor's trolley for transport.
workday: Works in bursts: several intensive days of labor followed by slower days searching for the next job.
At informal worksites he sets up simple safety perimeters and coordinates with a small team.
Breaks for a communal meal at midday, often shared with co-workers or a neighbor who brought food.
Uses brief pauses to check on his wife or run small errands (buying materials, paying a bill).
evening: Returns home, helps bathe the children, prepares a simple dinner, and listens to their school stories.
Pays any urgent bills in cash or through a mobile top-up, records the payment in his notebook envelope.
Spends 30–60 minutes on YouTube watching a repair tutorial or a soccer highlight reel before bed.
If worried about money, stays awake late calculating options and sometimes calls a sibling to ask for advice.
weekend: Visits the mercado for supplies early Saturday, gets small treats for the children.
Attends a short mass or community event on special dates and family celebrations.
Works on home improvement projects: sealing a roof area, fixing a door, or building a simple toy for his kid.
Receives extended family or friends for an informal barbecue; shares labor, food, and childcare responsibilities.

health.physical: Generally sturdy from manual labor but has chronic lower back stiffness from years of lifting heavy loads without formal training. Mild obesity around waistline due to inconsistent exercise and high-carb diet at times. Occasional lower respiratory infections tied to seasonal pollution and smoking. No diagnosed diabetes but a family history exists; monitors diet when possible. Dental health is poor — missing one molar and occasional toothache due to deferred dental care.
health.mental: Periodically experiences anxiety related to finances and future security; trouble sleeping when bills accumulate. Has moments of sadness and stress but has not been diagnosed with clinical depression. Proud and stoic; rarely seeks mental health services due to cost and stigma. Shows emotional warmth and occasional tears around family events.
health.medical_history: No major surgeries. Childhood vaccinations mostly complete per recollection but lacks formal records. Received stitches once after a work accident in his early twenties. Has had a hernia scare several years back but did not pursue full medical follow-up because of cost.
health.access_to_care: Uses public clinics (IMSS or local So often uses public clinics and health campaigns for children's vaccination). Relies on pharmacy remedies and home remedies for minor ailments. Concerned about expensive private care for acute issues.
health.health_behaviors: Tries to encourage children to eat vegetables, avoids heavy alcohol, sleeps when possible after long workdays, and values quick home remedies (e.g., herbal teas, warm compresses).

relationships.name: María Rivera
relationships.description: Married for eight years. Works part-time cleaning neighbor houses and sells homemade tamales on Saturdays to supplement family income. The relationship is affectionate and pragmatic: they make financial decisions together, co-parent closely, and share household chores. María is more cautious about taking risks and manages most of the household's paperwork. Their communication is generally open, though they both avoid explosive, prolonged arguments and try to resolve financial stress quietly.

relationships.name: Santiago Rivera
relationships.description: Age 4. Energetic, curious, sometimes stubborn. Enjoys helping his father with small projects and loves toy cars. Carlos is very proud of Santiago's ability to recite simple songs and counts.

relationships.name: Valentina Rivera
relationships.description: Age 2. She is clingy, still uses diapers, and sleeps with a small stuffed animal. Carlos often hums lullabies to help her sleep.

relationships.name: Doña Elena
relationships.description: Lives two blocks away. Provides occasional childcare and traditional cooking tips. Carlos respects her and often asks for advice; she has influence on family decisions during festivals and illnesses.

relationships.name: Raúl
relationships.description: Core friend in neighborhood; they look for work together and share tools. Raúl is the one who often suggests job leads and splits shared expenses when needed.

relationships.name: Marta
relationships.description: Lives in the State of Mexico, calls weekly. Offers emotional support and small financial help during emergencies when she can.

relationships.name: Señor López
relationships.description: An older man who hires Carlos for small home repairs and trusts him; provides honest references to other neighbors.

relationships.name: Local teacher at kindergarten
relationships.description: Knows Carlos by reputation as an involved parent. Offers updates on children's progress and sometimes suggests free programs.

other_facts: Grew up in a small town in Estado de México; moved to Mexico City at 16 to find work and opportunities.
First job was helping his uncle in a small carpentry shop, sweeping sawdust and learning to feed wood to the saw.
Dropped out of an afternoon vocational course when his father became ill and he needed to support the household.
Met his wife María at a neighborhood convenience store where she worked part-time; they began dating after sharing tamales.
Married in a modest civil ceremony with a small backyard party that his neighbors helped organize.
Has two small tattoos: a tiny cross on the inner wrist and his eldest child's name on his forearm.
Was once offered a semi-steady construction job but lost it after a disagreement with a foreman about overtime pay.
Keeps a faded lunchbox with stickers he and his son put on it — a small ritual of continuity.
Has a small savings envelope labeled 'escuela' where he tries to set aside money for the children’s school fees.
Once helped a neighbor rebuild a collapsing wall overnight after a storm; community remembers that effort.
Attends occasional community meetings where residents discuss safety, water delivery, and street lighting.
Has a photo album on his phone full of family photos, many of them taken with a cheap smartphone camera.
Was once robbed of a small amount of cash on a bus; the incident made him cautious about carrying large sums.
Has an old, half-fixed bicycle that he uses to ferry small loads and as a backup for short errands.
Once repaired a leaking roof using reclaimed metal sheets and friends who volunteered labor over a weekend.
Feels guilty about not being able to contribute more financially during the first year after their second child was born.
Has a small collection of tools left to him by an older neighbor who retired; treats those tools with care.
Occasionally receives informal loans from a rotating savings group (a 'tanda') with close friends.
Is ambivalent about official bank accounts; tried a small youth savings account once but found the fees confusing.
Celebrated his father's 60th birthday with a simple meal and a set of repaired chairs he built himself.
Was once asked to be best man at a friend's wedding but declined because of scheduling and worry about cost.
Volunteers occasionally at his children's preschool, helping with simple repairs or moving chairs.
Knows the best low-cost clinic for children’s vaccinations and recommends it to other parents.
Has an old cassette mixtape that his father recorded when Carlos was a child; listens to it rarely but with nostalgia.
Once nearly accepted a risky, high-paying job that friends discouraged him from taking because of legal gray areas.
Keeps a small notebook of emergency contacts, phone numbers for local hardware stores, and suppliers.
Learned to cook a modest set of family recipes from his mother and mother-in-law, blending tastes.
Has saved a small ritual: on the first payday after work, he buys the kids new crayons and a small treat.
Is learning to read short technical manuals more carefully through YouTube lessons to increase his employability.
Once helped a local school assemble a simple playground and felt proud when children used it.
Used to play soccer in a small neighborhood team in his early twenties; still meets occasionally for informal games.
Keeps a small shrine in his home with photos of deceased relatives and a candle on important dates.
Has a pragmatic superstition: carrying a particular token coin when going to job sites brings luck.
Dreams of teaching his son simple carpentry skills and handing over the worn hammer someday.
Owns a small prepaid life insurance policy purchased at a promotion months ago; thinks of it as a small safety blanket.
During a long drought in his neighborhood, organized a cooperative group to collect and share water deliveries.
Once received a scholarship offer for a formal trade course but could not accept due to family obligations.
Remembers a teacher in primary school who encouraged him to learn reading by rewarding small achievements — that memory is a motivator.
Has an itch to start a tiny weekend business selling tamales like his wife, but worries about competition and initial capital.
Is learning to use simple budgeting spreadsheets a neighbor showed him on a shared tablet at a community center.
